content: The Act is named the "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act". It requires a cost-benefit analysis for certain prudential regulations. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates that Federal banking agencies cannot impose prudential regulations stricter than international standards without publishing a rationale and cost-benefit analysis for public comment. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires Federal banking agencies to conduct a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis of any differences between prudential regulations and international standards, considering impacts on credit availability, market liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, and effects on employment and economic growth. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates Federal banking agencies to analyze the impact of differences between prudential regulations and international standards on credit availability, market liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, and effects on employment and economic growth. Additionally, agencies are prohibited from implementing prudential regulations that will result in regulations superseding international standards without considering these factors. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires Federal banking agencies to assess the effects of discrepancies between prudential regulations and international standards on credit availability, market liquidity, competitiveness of institutions, and impact on employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. Additionally, agencies cannot adopt prudential regulations that would supersede international standards without first seeking public input on repealing or amending the existing regulations. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires Federal banking agencies to assess discrepancies between prudential regulations and international standards. If a prudential regulation is superseded, the agency must propose to repeal or amend it, or provide a rationale for not doing so with a cost-benefit analysis. The "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" mandates Federal banking agencies to evaluate differences between prudential regulations and international standards. If a prudential regulation is replaced, the agency must justify not repealing or amending it, including a cost-benefit analysis. The Act requires Federal banking agencies to report to Congress within 180 days on prudential regulations that are more stringent than international standards or have been superseded. The Act mandates Federal banking agencies to report to Congress within 180 days on prudential regulations that exceed international standards or have been replaced. The Act requires Federal banking agencies to report to Congress on regulations exceeding international standards or replaced within 180 days. Definitions for "appropriate Federal banking agency" and "banking organization" are provided under this section. The curr_chunk defines "banking organization" as a depository institution or holding company under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act, and "corresponding international prudential standard" as an international standard related to prudential regulations. The curr_chunk defines "corresponding international prudential standard" as an international standard on which prudential regulations are based, derived from, or similar to, and "prudential regulation" as any rule related to capital, leverage, liquidity requirements for banking organizations. The term "prudential regulation" refers to rules regarding capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. It includes regulations that set minimum requirements for capital, debt, or liquid assets based on various measures. Prudential regulation implements international standards for capital, leverage, debt, and liquidity requirements in banking organizations. Prudential regulation implements international standards for capital, leverage, debt, or liquidity based on international prudential standards. An international prudential standard is any standard adopted by an international institution, including the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board, related to capital, leverage, liquidity requirements, or similar requirements for banking organizations. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board set international standards for capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. These standards may include minimum requirements for capital, debt, or liquid assets, as well as conditions based on measures of capital, leverage, debt, or liquidity. The term "superseded prudential regulation" refers to a regulation that addresses similar risks or achieves similar goals as an international standard for capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements set by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board. The term "superseded prudential regulation" means a regulation that addresses similar risks or achieves similar goals as an international standard for capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements.
